Posts.Content: Hematuria=tumor, stone, or infection. I would lean toward a stone, probably in the bladder.
Posts.Title: Hopefully not a major issue

Posts.Content: Hematuria=tumor, stone, or infection. I would lean toward a stone, probably in the bladder.
Posts.Title: Hopefully not a major issue

Posts.Content: Well, I don't know your numbers but if you are Low Risk disease or even Intermediate you should do fine. I had low dose brachy for Gleason 4+3. My prostate size was under 30 cc which was a big help. You may have a catheter for 24 hours, a mild inconvenience. The biggest problem I had was nocturia, 3-4 times a night, and it took fooooooorever to urinate, could not find the answer as to the delay, no position, activity that seemed to help. Was on pretty high dose of Cardura, somewhat helpful. Lasted about four months. Had some short term ED that responded well to Viagra, don't need it now. Urination pretty normal, a bit of discomfort. No problem at all with incontinence, just a non issue with brachy. PSA will sloooooooowly come down over many months, don't expect any plummeting numbers, should just gradually decline over two years. Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Brachy side affects after treament

Posts.Content: Yes, the Cardura was for the nocturia, I was on 8 mg total a day. Seemed to help more than the Flomax I tried but basically it just took many months to get over that part of it. Kind of wore me down after a while just not getting to sleep through the night. Now I am on 2 mg Cardura and no nocturia at all, very nice. I don't recall any particular discomfort in the perineal area 6 weeks after brachy but I wasn't bike riding. I was out cross country skiing quite a bit though without any problems.

Posts.Title: Brachy side affects after treament

Posts.Content: A little hard to follow this thread since it has been sliced and diced many times. What I understand is that your husband was diagnosed with high risk PC metastatic to bone and seminal vesicles. He responded well to combination therapy and PSA had dropped. A least this one follow up bone scan was negative after that treatment. I suspect the bone scan was ordered since the initial scan was positive and provided a comparison study(cost and convenience may have played a role as well) Certainly PET/CT scans are more accurate but I am not clear about the value of serial bone scans vs. PET/CT scans in this situation. I am not even clear about the value of serial plain bone scans vs. serial PSAs unless there is consideration of local treatment of metastatic disease. In that case a PET/CT or even an MR scan would be preferable. I would concentrate on the good news of his dropping PSA, that is really remarkable and encouraging. My very sincere congratulations. I think that description of MDs ordering more tests for patients with good insurance is called economic credentialing. At least in my hospital that practice pretty much was stopped when cost controls were instituted 10-15 years ago by the insurance companies. Maybe some health care systems still do it? I have been lucky to be a patient in the Kaiser system which uses evidence based medicine rather than any profit motive. And speaking of wasting money, a bone scan is a definite waste of money for well differentiated PCs with PSA <10. (Some would say 20.) They are useful for stage T3, Gleason >7, or PSA >20 and in those circumstances a more accurate test would be preferable. I saw three urologists, two radiation oncologists for my Gleason 4+3, PSA 6.0 PC and each and everyone of them offered a bone scan but said they did not think it was necessary. I agreed. More men should get that kind of advice.
Posts.Title: Conventional Bone Scan vs. Sodium Flouride Bone Scan

Posts.Content: I had IMRT in October 2012 followed by LD Brachytherarpy in December 2012. Started on Cardura 2mg at bedtime prior to IMRT, gradually increased my dosage to 4mg twice a day after the brachytherapy. Now I am back to 6 mg per day, can't really get much lower without recurrence of nocturia. I tried Flomax which did not work as well as the Cardura, which is also much cheaper. I expect to be on the Cardura for a few more months.
Posts.Title: Flomax post Bracchytheraphy

Posts.Content: Two things that strike me, one, he only a seven core biopsy and two of the cores were positive? Add that to a PSA of 32, seems like a strange combination. Make sure if he chooses EBRT that the facility uses IMRT, much more accurate and fewer side effects. I had IMRT and other than the daily visits for treatment it was a pretty benign experience, some mild urinary symptoms, no GI symptoms at all. At his age I would think that choosing a low side effect treatment would be a paramount consideration. I cannot imagine why surgery would be considered at his age when HT or RT offer equally good treatments with much fewer immediate and long term side effects.

Posts.Title: Radiotherapy or hormone therapy at age 78

Posts.Content: I do not know the time to reach nadir PSA for IMRT only but I do remember that the time to reach nadir after combination IMRT and LDS brachytherapy is about 24 months because that is what I researched for my own treatment. My preop PSA was around 6.5 and at 24 months post treatment it was about .36. It is now .23 and I am about 28 months or so post treatment. As long as the PSA continues its downward course it should be fine. I know there can be a PSA bump but that occurs later than the 3 months or so that you are at now. I am sure there are information that charts PSA over time following IMRT that you can access.
Posts.Title: Little bit confused.

Posts.Content: Bright Sky. As others have suggested, it is hard to form an opinion with limited information and that forces one to make some assumptions. If your uncle was a candidate for Active Surveillance, at the minimum he likely had a Gleason 6 score and a PSA less than 10. Depending on the protocol he would have had at least one follow up exam by now, either a MR scan or a repeat biopsy. That information would be useful. But given his situation now, the first step would be a T3 MR scan, or even a T2 with endorectal coil to visualize the extent of disease. The fact that the bone scan and CT scan were negative is good evidence that there is less likelihood of bone metastases or lymph node spread. So the next best step would be a referral back to the urologist and a MR scan. The current information you have should not exclude surgery for primary treatment.

Posts.Title: Prostate problems

Posts.Content: Sounds like prostatitis to me. Should be pretty easy to treat although an extended course of antibiotics sometimes is needed.
Posts.Title: Could My Husband Have Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: Sounds like prostatitis to me. Should be pretty easy to treat although an extended course of antibiotics sometimes is needed.
Posts.Title: Could My Husband Have Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: The PSA screening is applied to all men over a certain age, and a good screening test should be sensitive so as to not miss many cancers and have enough specificity so minimize the amount of invasive testing. PSA does not do that very well but so far it is the best we have. PSA testing after primary treatment is a different ball game. You know what the normal value is, it's zero, no questions asked. So the threshold for being abnormal is pretty easily defined. You might think that a PSA of say 1.0 after prostatectomy could represent either normal or cancer cells, but since the prostate is removed en bloc, and normal cells don't migrate out of the capsule, the assumption is that the PSA is coming from either extracapsular extension of cancer cells or cancer cells in the SV, lymph nodes, or metastases. (Not quite as simple for PSA levels post radiation)
Posts.Title: Interesting article/interview on the history of the PSA test

Posts.Content: Could you give us your age, PSA history, and prostate size as measured by on the ultrasound when your biopsy was done?
Posts.Title: Recent Bioipsy Results

Posts.Content: My impression is that for recurrent disease it is better to start hormone treatment earlier rather than later and that mortality is less when started early. Of course, the problem is not so much when to start treatment but if you should. And that depends on the PSA doubling time and pathology. Hormonal treatment would also depend on localization of the recurrence, is it in the prostatic fossa, is it in lymph nodes, or is there metastatic disease to organs or bone. Radiation or cryotherapy might be more effective depending on the circumstances. Certainly a PSA rise following surgery for Gleason 8 would be treated entirely different that one with Gleason 6 pathology.
Posts.Title: At what stage does PC spread

Posts.Title: At what stage does PC spread

Posts.Content: I only read the transcript but I did not see anything that suggested the PSA could diagnose prostate cancer. I think the 80% false positive rate referred to the value of PSA screening, not detecting prostate cancer. I can't imagine anyone arguing that the PSA test is a particularly good screening test for PC, but it sadly it is all there is. What was interesting about the article is that the PSA was originally developed to follow prostate cancer patients after primary treatment and it was adopted as a screening test without adequate investigation. And of course, it was approved with what sounds like political pressure and financial motives on the part of the medical industry. (I am not trying to resurrect an old argument about PSA screening saving lives.) What Dr. Albin was at least suggesting was that because of PSA screening lots of health care dollars have been spent on tests that might have better been spent on prostate cancer research. Of course, that would only happen in a perfect world where evidence based medicine is practiced. And by the way, a prostate biopsy is not 100% accurate for diagnosing prostate cancer if you are referring to its sensitivity. Far from it.
Posts.Title: Interesting article/interview on the history of the PSA test

Posts.Content: I would second the recommendation of brachytherapy. The only difficulty is the accuracy of the biopsy and the possibility that the Gleason 3+4 can be a 4+3. The addition of IMRT would be a consideration if you wanted to cover that possibility. HDR is adequate for Gleason 3+4, at least when I did my research last year. But since my biopsy showed G 4+3, the decision was pretty easy to include IMRT. There might be some value in a T3 parametric MRI to look for signs of more aggressive disease and if that were seen, then including IMRT would make a lot of sense. I would also discuss with the treating MD as to the value of a bone scan and CT scan as part of the initial evaluation. I have read nothing that suggests they are useful for PC with your type of numbers.
Posts.Title: Just got my first bad biopsy results. Thoughts? Suggestions?

Posts.Title: Interesting article/interview on the history of the PSA test

Posts.Content: I think that Cyberknife treats the entire prostate gland and probably can be fine tuned to treat seminal vesicles if necessary. The only focal treatment I have heard about is color Doppler guided ablation therapy. Although encouraging news, five years seems awfully short to be making claims of cure for low and intermediate risk PC.
Posts.Title: SBRT 5 year study released. Claimed "98% cure rate"

Posts.Content: Hi David. A couple of points to consider. First, even though a negative DRE is better news than a positive DRE, to say "that it indicates that the cancer is contained in the prostate" is overly optimistic. The only test that will definitively answer that question is the surgical pathology. Sometime in the near future MR imaging may provide that information as well. You can use various nomograms to estimate the risk of extracapsular extension, seminal vesicle involvement, and positive lymph nodes but those numbers have to be taken as statistics rather than prognoses. Secondly, the side effects of radiation occur much later than 1-2 years, at least the major side effects of incontinence and ED. You can evaluate that statement for yourself but I think the time range is much longer. And finally, even at your early age you should seriously consider brachytherapy (low or high dose) with IMRT performed by an experienced center such as Radiotherapy Clinics of Georgia. Their information is a bit inflated but there is enough information on their website to make it worthwhile.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed in Atlanta

Posts.Content: I am in agreement with your physician. He needs to recover and repair from surgery first. And secondly he needs a post-op PSA to know how successful the RP was and to determine if he needs further treatment. Also that PSA level will serve as a baseline to judge success of treatment. Remember that even high risk prostate cancer is much better than other cancers and sometimes when we use the term high risk it just sounds bad, especially when people start using the term "aggressive". It just sounds bad. But if you use one risk assessment tool (there are many out there), the risk of recurrence at five years is about 30%, and the risk of death at five years is about 3%. And using that tool, the fact that he went from Gleason 5+3 to Gleason 4+5 does not change the risk assessment (at least using this particular tool). Things are not so dire that you need to jump into this with both shotguns blazing.
Posts.Title: Now a Gleason 9

Posts.Content: It's called climacturia, I think the incidence is about 15% following surgery. Not brought up much as a side effect of surgery and I am unclear as to how long it lasts. Shows just how complex an operation a radical prostatectomy can be, lots of plumbing that needs to be kept straight while nipping and tucking.
Posts.Title: masturbation after surgery

Posts.Content: I have not heard of anyone doing nerve grafts for many years. I know of one situation, maybe 15 years ago where a nerve graft was done as part of an open prostatectomy. The nerve was taken from the posterior tibial nerve I think. I do not know if the graft was successful. My suspicion is that you no longer read about nerve grafting since the development and widespread use of RALP and surgical techniques that allow for sparing of the relevant nerve bundles. Just an educated guess.
Posts.Title: Nerve Graphs...any one?

Posts.Content: I have not heard of anyone doing nerve grafts for many years. I know of one situation, maybe 15 years ago where a nerve graft was done as part of an open prostatectomy. Just an educated guess.
Posts.Title: Nerve Graphs...any one?

Posts.Content: I am 62 years old, diagnosed with PC 7/2011, PSA 7.12, 1 of 18 core biopsies positive for Gleason 6, 26% cancer. Prostate size was 29. DRE negative. Chose AS for treatment. PSAs over the last year have been 6.23. 6.38, 5.4, and 6.32. Repeat biopsy 8/3/2011 showed 3 of 14 cores positive: Gleason 4+3, 33%, Gleason 4+3 68%, Gleason 3+4 30%. The previous area of cancer this time showed atypia. Prostate size 30. DRE negative. All cancers on the left side of the prostate. I have read Walsh, Chodak, Scholz and other sources. I am not inclined for RP because of quality of life issues. I am leaning toward high dose brachy. Added to the mix is I changed insurance from Blue Cross to Kaiser Perm in the last six months, live in the Pacific Northwest where there is limited Kaiser Perm radiation treatment centers, at least I think that is right. Discussed briefly with my urologist who suggested RALP with nerve sparing on the right. My perspective is the nomograms are not encouraging for a surgical cure. Anyone go through a similar process, or start off with similar numbers as my last biopsy? I am very interested in what treatment was chosen and especially interested in experiences with high dose brachtherapy.
Posts.Title: Active Surveillance didn't work, now what?
